data.title: Tank: Stagnation grips Saskatchewan as population growth stalls
data.meta_description: Outside of Saskatoon, Regina and Prince Albert, population in the once booming province has become as stagnant as a slough.
data.text:
Article content

Saskatchewan is stagnating.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Tank: Stagnation grips Saskatchewan as population growth stalls Back to video

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Over the last five years, the province’s population grew by just 3.1 per cent, well behind the national rate of 5.2 per cent and ninth among provinces, according to Statistics Canada census data.

That marks a stark reversal of the previous 10 years, when Saskatchewan ranked among the top provinces for growth. From 2011 to 2016, it grew by 6.3 per cent, higher than the national growth of five per cent.

Article content

But outside the three largest cities — Saskatoon (up 7.7 per cent), Regina (5.3 per cent) and Prince Albert (5.1 per cent) and a handful of communities near them — the population has stayed static or declined.

Aside from Martensville (9.3 per cent) and Warman (12.7), both Saskatoon bedroom communities, growth in Saskatchewan’s other 11 cities trailed the provincial average.

Humboldt did the best among these at 2.8 per cent, but that’s disappointing when you consider the same city grew by 13.6 per cent from 2006 to 2011.

Estevan did the worst with a decline of 5.5 per cent or 632 people, a stunning drop for the southeastern city that expanded by 1,399 people or 13.8 per cent over the previous decade.

North Battleford’s population dropped by 3.3 per cent and is home to fewer people than a decade ago.

The population of Moose Jaw, the province’s fourth largest city, decreased slightly, as did those of Meadow Lake, Melfort, Melville and Yorkton.

Weyburn, Swift Current and Lloydminster registered modest growth below two per cent.

If you remove Saskatoon, Regina and Prince Albert and the growth they attract, you’ve got a population that’s as stagnant as a slough.

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

And the growth halos around those cities don’t extend far. Pilot Butte, a Regina bedroom community, exploded by 23.4 per cent. But Balgonie, about 12 kilometres farther from the Queen City, decreased slightly.

Shellbrook, about 45 kilometres west of Prince Albert, grew by 4.6 per cent, while Rosthern, about 75 km south, dropped 5.1 per cent.

Both of those towns are located in Premier Scott Moe’s constituency.

Saskatchewan remains the most rural province west of the Atlantic time zone, but the population in areas classified as rural dropped by nearly two per cent over the last five years.

The decline in Saskatchewan’s rural population ranks third behind Newfoundland and Labrador and Alberta amid a stable national rural population.

Despite the most provocative name in the province, the village of Climax suffered a drop of nearly 30 per cent to 137 people, who presumably are still satisfied living there.

About a third of Saskatchewan’s population still lives in rural areas, but another decline of the magnitude of the last five years will push the rural share below 30 per cent for the first time. From 2011 to 2016, Saskatchewan’s rural population remained stable.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

The global shift from rural to urban has been happening in Saskatchewan since its founding, but the trend to larger urban areas is also accelerating.

Family farms have transformed into factories with fewer owners and fewer people working on them. In 2020, the number of people employed in agriculture in the province declined by 22 per cent to about 30,000.

Saskatchewan is beginning to look like a smaller Alberta, with two large, growing urban areas depleting the population in the rest of the province.

But urban growth is slowing, too. Saskatoon grew by nearly 11 per cent from 2011 to 2016 and Regina grew by more than 11 per cent. That means Regina’s growth has slowed to half of what it was.

Perhaps those growth rates proved unsustainable or maybe Saskatchewan has reached a tipping point.

Regardless, Moe’s Saskatchewan Party government has made growth a key plank of its appeal.

The party’s impenetrable political armour since it swept to power in 2007 has been forged by pointing repeatedly and derisively to population drops under the previous NDP government

Saskatchewan’s population undeniably declined under the NDP’s watch from 1991 to 2007, but the province first dropped below one million people during the second term of Grant Devine’s Progressive Conservatives in the 1980s.

Advertisement 5

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Boasting about a record of population growth now will ring hollow throughout most of an emptier Saskatchewan.

Phil Tank is the digital opinion editor at the Saskatoon StarPhoenix.
